title: brussels massive financial gap no deal
story: Budget commissioner Günther Oettinger warns Germany will be forced to fork out hundreds of millions to plug the massive gap left by Britain walking away without having to hand over its £billion orce fee.Throughout the negotiations, we have approached the EU in good faith and offered to honour our commitments.But Brussels’ stubborn refusal to compromise has pushed us ever closer to leaving without a deal. And, without our cash, the EU now realises there will be a massive black hole in their coffers.EU chiefs mistakenly thought they had us over a barrel and could use their leverage to get whatever they wanted.But they are now waking up to the fact that Theresa May’s Brexit deal is unlikely to get the nod and, with no deal legally our default position, a clean break looms.The refusal to give our PM any concessions does not look so wise now.The Sun has long questionedthe EU would ever prioritise their economies and citizens’ jobs over a zealous desire to punish Britain for leaving.Perhaps Mr Oettinger’s comments suggest that reality is finally dawning.IT is shocking that Britain has just TWO boats to police , miles of shoreline.Organised gangs are taking advantage of our easily penetrable coast to traffick desperate people who will risk their lives in one of the world’s busiest shipping lanes to get here.As many as  people have tried to cross over from France in just two months. title: javan rhino population wiped out tsunami krakatoa
story: There are believed to be just  of the animals left in Ujung Kulon National Park, which lies in the shadow of the killer volcano that triggered Saturdays mega-wave.Two park officials were among the  killed by the tsunami, and numerous park buildings were also destroyed when it struck Indonesia on Saturday.But the Javan rhinos left in the park - the only ones remaining anywhere in the world - are reported to have escaped unscathed following the eruption of Mount Krakatoa.“It’s become our duty to work harder to find a second habitat because the danger is real,” park chief Mamat Rahmat told AFP.“We’re lucky that the tsunami did not affect the Javan rhinos this time. But the threat is there and we need to act accordingly.”Widodo Ramono, head of the Rhino Conservation Foundation of Indonesia, added: “If you’ve only got one habitat and there’s another tsunami, the rhinos could be wiped out completely.”Plans to find a second home for the ultra-rare species have been ongoing for more than eight years but to no avail.The size of the habitat, climate, food and water sources and safety from poachers are said to be among the key criteria.The Javan rhinos are the most threatened of the five rhino species in the world - and are listed as Critically Endangered on the IUCN Red List.Earlier today it was reported Mount Krakatoa could trigger a second tsunami at any time - as flights were rerouted to avoid a column of ash and smoke.Authorities in Indonesia have widened a no-go zone to three miles as the volcano alert status was raised to the second-highest level in response to the threat of further devastation.Saturdays eruption caused part of the Anak Krakatau island to collapse into the Sunda Strait, generating ft tsunami waves that killed at least  in Java and Sumatra.The government has warned people to stay half a mile away from the shore because another tsunami could be triggered by Krakatoas continuing eruptions.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cairo egypt tourist bus explosion latest
story: The coach was hit by an explosion from an improvised device hidden near a wall on Marioutiya Street at about .pm local time.About two hours later the bus could be seen behind a police cordon with one of its sides badly damaged and the windows blown out.Dozens of police and firefighters were at the scene, on a narrow side street close to the ring road.It is unclear who carried out the suspected terror attack.Three Vietnamese tourists and an Egyptian guide were killed and at least  others injured, authorities said.This is the first attack to target foreign tourists in almost two years.No immediate claim of responsibility was reported.But Islamist extremists including some linked to ISIS are active in Egypt and have targeted foreign visitors in the past.The outrage takes place as the countrys vital tourism industry is showing signs of recovery after years in the doldrums because of the political turmoil following the  uprising that toppled former leader Hosni Mubarak.The protests linked to the uprising and the bombing of a Russian airliner shortly after it took off from Sharm el-Sheikh in  caused tourist numbers to plunge.The last deadly attack on foreign tourists in Egypt was in July , when two Germans were stabbed to death in the Red Sea resort of Hurghada.An investigator at the scene said the device had likely been planted near the wall.The injured from today’s bombing were taken to the nearby Al Haram hospital, where Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly told local TV that the guide had died from his injuries.Mr Madbouly told Extra News TV: The bus deviated from the route secured by the security forces.We have been in contact with the embassy of Vietnam to contain the impact of the incident, and what is important now is to take care of the injured.It will likely prompt authorities to further tighten security around churches and associated facilities ahead of the New years Eve celebrations and next months Christmas celebrations of the Coptic Orthodox Church, the dominant denomination among Egypts estimated  million Christians.Over the past two years, militant attacks against Christians in Egypt usually targeting churches or buses carrying pilgrims to remote desert monasteries have killed over a hundred people.The FCO has stopped short of advising against any travel to Cairo and Giza.But it has warned of threats to foreigners posted on websites and social media.

title: iran ransom demand nazanin 500m
story: Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt has secretly agreed to settle a  year-old debt to Tehran as the price to free the sickly dual national, who turned  on Boxing Day.But The Sun can reveal that diplomats are now locked in a major haggle over how much interest should be paid on the £m historical debt from a botched military deal.A court ruled in  that the UK owes Tehran the money after pulling out of an agreement to sell it , Chieftain tanks after the Shah was overthrown in .But sources have revealed that Iran is insisting that an interest rate of up to % is levied on the cash, pushing the total close to £m.Iran will next month haul the British government back to court in London as it mounts a renewed legal bid to enforce the payment.A source said: “Our diplomats cannot agree a figure for the interest with Tehran, which is slowing everything down.“Nazanin’s freedom is all intended to be part of a grand bargain, including the money for the tanks, but the Foreign Office is desperate not to make it look like that.”The fresh blow for Nazanin’s campaigners came as she marked the landmark of , days behind bars yesterday.Husband Richard Ratclfe also used the grim anniversary to issue a fresh demand on the Foreign Secretary to ramp Britain’s protests.Mr Ratclfe said: “We want two things to happen. This should go to the UN Security Council now. It’s not just Nazanin, there are many Britons and Americans being held by Iran.“We should also raise it to the level of a formal dispute between Britain and Iran, which hasn’t happened yet. That would give Nazanin diplomatic protection.”Mr Hunt stepped up the verbal pressure on Tehran yesterday by branding its actions as “monstrous” and “totally unjust”.He also accused Iran of holding Brits like Nazanin prisoner as “a tool of diplomatic leverage”.The Foreign Secretary added: “Iran is a country which has a great civilisation behind it, one of the oldest civilisations in the world, they want to be respected by other countries - this is not the way to do it, to imprison an innocent woman like this”.The Government has previously insisted international sanctions on Iran’s defence ministry made it impossible for a deal to be done.But campaigners have insisted it could instead pay Iran’s central bank the money, which has already been set aside in a holding account.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british divers george medal new years honours
story: Richard Stanton and John Volanthen, the first to reach the  stranded children and their team coach but the least keen on giving media interviews, were given the accolade.Fellow ers Christopher Jewell and Jason Mallinson also receive the Queen’s Gallantry Medal.Colleagues Joshua Bratchley, Lance Corporal Connor Roe and Vernon Unsworth, the ex-pat suing Tesla entrepreneur Elon Musk for labelling him a “pedo guy”, all get MBEs for their roles in the dramatic Thai cave rescue, which gripped the world in June.Mr Unsworth said: “This was a team effort, and I’m very honoured to have been recognised, particularly as you don’t engage in a major rescue expecting this outcome. For me, after saving the boys, this is the icing on the cake.”Mr Jewell, , from Cheddar, Somerset, ing officer at the British Cave Rescue Council , praised the “amazing support” they had during and after the rescue.He said: “People from all over the country and the world have reached out to us to offer congratulations and express their gratitude.“Behind every one of the cave ers being honoured is a supporting cast of family, friends, rescue volunteers and employers.”Mr Bratchley, , a Met Office meteorologist based at RAF Valley, in Anglesey, North Wales, said it was “incredible to be recognised in such a way”.He said: “We’d like to sincerely thank everyone who helped us in any capacity and make it clear that such a rescue could never work otherwise - the ing was just the tip of a very large iceberg.”The British ers answered a call by Thai authorities to join a major search after the group disappeared in the Tham Luang Nang Non cave, in Chiang Rai province, on June .THE Whitehall mandarin whose department was at the centre of the John Worboys parole fiasco has been given the fourth most senior Order of Chivalry.Richard Heaton, Ministry of Justice permanent secretary, will get the Order of the Bath.His department oversees the Parole  Board, whose decision to free black cab rapist Worboys was reversed only after a Sun-backed legal challenge.One victim said yesterday: “The decision to release Worboys happened very much on his watch.”HMRC chief executive Jon Thompson also gets the Order of the Bath.Aged between  and ,they entered the caves and became marooned in the dark until Mr Stanton, , from Coventry, and Mr Volanthen, , from Bristol, reached them on July .Seven Royal Thai Navy Seals and a medic gave the youngsters ing lessons in the cave while authorities decided whether to wait for conditions to improve or bring the boys out straight away.Both were fraught with danger and one former navy Seal helping in the rescue effort died from a lack of oxygen during his mission.It was eventually decided to guide the boys out through nearly a mile of flooded caverns and tight passages where they emerged on July  - after  days underground.The four ers are among  recipients of bravery awards announced at the same time as the main honours list.They include seven firefighters who saved elderly residents from a serious blaze at a care home in Cheshunt in .Wayne Ansell, Simon Best, Daniel Cooper, Ricky Davis, Christopher Meadows, Radoslaw Przemyslaw Pejka and Simon Waddingham, all of Hertfordshire Fire and Rescue Service, get Queen’s Gallantry Medals in recognition of their acts.And a Queen’s Commendation for Bravery also goes to -year-old Joe Rowlands, from Cheshire, whose sustained efforts saved his father Paul from drowning after their kayak capsized off Anglesey.THERESA May was  accused of handing out honours in a “shameless” bid to “blunt criticism” of her Brexit deal.It came as arch-Brexiteer John Redwood received his knighthood in the New Year’s Honours List.He was among three MPs given the accolade alongside former Tory minister Gary Streeter, who is already backing the PM’s deal, and Labour’s deputy chief whip Alan Campbell.Lib Dem MP Layla Moran said: “I cannot see how it is anything but a desperate attempt to blunt criticism of the Prime Minister’s Brexit deal.”But it appears Mr Redwood will not be swayed.He posted a blog just before the announcement of his honour titled “Eight things wrong with the Withdrawal Agreement”.The PM’s appointment of three Conservative MPs to the Privy Council was also branded a “desperate” attempt by the Government to shore up support for her deal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sajid javid huddersfield asian grooming tweet
story: A politician who doesn’t retract his comments just because they upset the kind of people who make a career out of being upset.That politician is Sajid Javid, the Home Secretary — though perhaps we should refer to him as the Home Truth Secretary because he has been delivering a fair few of those recently.This week, Javid was offered an opportunity to backtrack on something he said a few months ago.And amazingly — given we live in an era of spineless politics in which MPs are forever repenting for something they said — he turned down the opportunity.Javid’s speech-crime was to tweet about Muslim grooming gangs.In October, he tweeted a heartfelt comment about the Huddersfield grooming gang —  men who were found guilty of  offences against  girls.They pursued a “campaign of rape and abuse” against their vulnerable victims, said the judge at Leeds Crown Court.Javid described their predatory behaviour — including against a teenage girl who had the mental age of a seven-year-old — as “vile and wicked”.In his tweet commenting on the case — he referred to the  men as “sick Asian paedophiles”.Cue instant meltdown in PC circles.For Javid to use the A-word — “Asian” — was nasty and offensive, they spluttered.Like a modern-day Inquisition, the permanently outraged Twitterati denounced Javid for “racialising” the crimes in Huddersfield.Labour MP David Lammy said Javid had increased “the risk of violence and abuse against minorities”.Labour’s Diane Abbott slammed him for “attributing these crimes to one ethnic group”.But here is the thing —we are talking about the Huddersfield crimes, as Javid was, it is absolutely right to “attribute these crimes to one ethnic group”.As the BBC reported at the time, the  Huddersfield groomers were “all British Asians, mainly of Pakistani heritage”.Javid, who is also of Pakistani heritage, was telling the truth. Every word of his tweet was correct — these men are sick, they are paedophiles and they are Asian.When politicians are condemned for telling the truth, for stating plain-as-day facts, you know we live in scarily censorious times.So, this week, Javid was right to turn down an invitation to “rethink” his October tweet.He was on the Today programme on Radio . A guest presenter — the British-Pakistani novelist Kamila Shamsie — asked himhe thought his tweet might have fuelled hate crimes. Coolly, and with rare principle, Javid said that of course politicians must be “careful with their language”.Butyou look at recent high-profile cases of gang-based sexual exploitation, “there is a high proportion of men that have Pakistani heritage”, he said.He’s right.Rotherham, Oxford, Rochdale, Derby, Telford, Newcastle, Huddersfield . . . across England there have been awful grooming-gang cases, where the perpetrators have largely been Muslim men and the victims white working-class girls.We must be free to talk about this. To analyse it. To ask how such a terrible situation came about where vulnerable, mostly white girls are preyed upon by wicked, mainly Muslim men.But we are not free to talk about it. Anybody who raises the issue of Muslim grooming gangs risks being branded as foul, a racist, a troublemaker whose words will fuel hate crimes.Indeed, Javid has been subjected to genuine racist abuse for speaking out on the issue.Vile, hard-left tweeters have denounced him as an “Uncle Tom” and a “coconut”.Such disgusting racist insults reveal where the real prejudice lies in this debate — not in Javid’s concerned comments, but in the PC outrage that effectively says to him: “Shut up, Coconut.” Javid was not being prejudiced but many of the supposed progressives raging against him have been.It is all a sign of the times. From Conservatives such as Javid, to Labour MP Sarah Champion and radical feminists such as Julie Bindel, anyone who expresses concern about Pakistani-heritage grooming gangs can expect to be bombarded with abuse.But a nation that cannot discuss its communal tensions is a nation that is in very serious trouble.That signicant numbers of Muslim men are abusing signicant numbers of white working-class girls suggests “multicultural Britain” is a fractured, sometimes ugly place — and we must be at liberty to talk about this.Shushing debate about Muslim grooming gangs is insulting not only to the victims of those gangs, but to Britain’s Muslim community, too.It suggests they are too fragile, too weak, to cope with honest debate about problems and crimes within their communities.So let us be thankful for Sajid Javid — a politician who is willing to look modern Britain in the face and ask it some dficult but essential questions.This is a Tory to watch.Their latest wheeze is to force restaurants and supermarkets to impose “calorie caps” on their dishes.Public Health England is thinking about stopping supermarkets from selling sarnies that have more than  calories and capping restaurant meals at  calories. This would effectively mean using the power of the state to force us slovenly, greedy plebs to go on diets.It’s so paternalistic.Here’s a radical idea – bugger off and let people eat whatever they want.Our lunchtime triple-decker sandwich and occasional restaurant blowout are none of your business.TALK about a self-fulfilling prophecy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mod pictures of year troops in action
story: From war games in Oman to tackling the Taliban in Kabul, this inspirational picture set really does show off the awesome capabilities of Britains military.One awe-inspiring shot shows a fearsome Challenger  battle tack silhouetted against a desert sunset.It was demonstrating its manoeuvre abilities as part of part Exercise Sa Sareea  in Oman.The bilateral war games saw , UK personnel training alongside , Omani troops in a bid to develop joint operations between the two countries.One shot shows a giant Chinook helicopter fast-roping Royal Marines onto a beach in the Indian Ocean as part of a simulated invasion.The RAF also conducted war games in Arizona, US - with one picture showing a serviceman staring out of his helicopter at a Marine Corps airbase.Another image shows the Red Arrows tearing across the sky above the Mall as part of the RAFs centenary celebrations.The celebrations also included a flypast from a WW-era Spitfire fighter plane.

title: royal mail apologises stamp uk troops
story: The issue — titled D-Day Allied soldiers and medics wade ashore — marks the Norm­andy invasion on June , .But it features a picture of American forces in Dutch New Guinea.Royal Mail’s managing director of letters Stephen Agar said: “I am sincerely sorry for this mistake and the hurt it has caused, in particular veterans and those who lost loved ones. We have let you down.”He said the stamp will not be part of its collection due out in June to mark the th anniversary of D-Day.The mix-up was pointed out after the design was posted online. Historian Paul Woodadge wrote: “Please correct this or you’ll look like idiots.”The Spirit of Normandy Trust said: “This error is very unfortunate but it’s not the first time one has been made about D-Day.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: couple ivf facebook mum treatment
story: Marisha Chaplin, , gave birth to her daughter Isla on Saturday after social media good Samaritans clubbed together for her and partner Jon Hibbs.The new mum-of-two told the BBC: Its amazing, it really is.Its better than we ever imagined and we didnt think we would ever get to this point.The pair met as teenagers while having cancer treatment in  and started trying for a baby when she was just .Marisha, from Cotgrave, Notts, knew her treatment was likely to cause her fertility problems.She said: I was told by the time I was  my oies would give up.At  my gynaecologist said You need to try for children sooner rather than lateryou want them.They began IVF treatment using donor eggs when Ms Chaplin was  and had Evie in May .But they were unable to afford a second round of treatment.It was then that she joined the Facebook group May Babies , for other mothers who had given birth at the same time.Members secretly raised the amount before creating a video to surprise the couple and played it to them via Facebook Live.The couple were able to use frozen embryos left over from their previous treatment, meaning Evie and Isla are full genetic sisters.In the clip, Ms Chaplin is seen crying even before being told they had raised the money.She said: We didnt ever think we had the chance to have another little one and the fact shes here is so surreal.Even when she came out we were like Is that our baby  Is this real

title: fisherman overboard saved nets five miles
story: Nathan Rogers, , had a miraculous escape in icy seas thanks to a string of coincidences, said rescuers.He was finally spotted trailing  yards from his boat Semper Fidelis — Latin for “always loyal” — after it ploughed into a pier at the harbour mouth in Newyln, Cornwall.The skipper of another fishing boat then held on to him until a leboat picked him up.Nathan was treated in hospital for hypothermia before being allowed home.Penlee leboat coxswain Patch Harvey said: “I’ve been a fisherman and a leboatman over  years and never seen something like that.“He managed to cling on to some hydraulic hoses among the netting.If they had snapped he wouldn’t be here now.It was flat calm too.If it had been rough he wouldn’t have been able to hang on.Orthe boat had been going in any other direction, nobody would have known.”He added: “While we were towing another boat we actually passed his boat not knowing he was over the side.We’re all chuffed he’s all right.”Nathan had been adjusting nets when he fell and was dragged along at six knots.Louis Matisse, , saw him from the beach at around .pm on Thursday.He said: “I told my dad to phone .”Nathan said: “I would just like to thank everyone involved in my rescue.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit mp plot referendum
story: The House of Commons could bar ministers from raising taxes - bringing the state to a standstill.The drastic step is proposed as a way of forcing Theresa May to carry out a dramatic U-turn and back a rerun of the  vote.Pro-EU campaign group Best for Britain has published a new report recommending the wrecking tactic.It suggests MPs should vote down the PMs deal next month, then vote to rule out a No Deal outcome.The document says: The clearest opportunity for replacing no deal as the default option is through political pressure via the Finance Bill.The key point is that income tax and corporation tax are annual taxes, authorisation of which runs out at the end of the tax year.MPs could in theory pass an amendment blocking the Government from collecting the levies, which make up a third of all tax revenue.The proposed amendment to the Finance Bill would state that no taxes can be collected until the PM calls a second referendum on Brexit.It would be up to Speaker John Bercow to decide whether or not the amendment can be voted on.Another suggestion would see MPs block the Government from bringing any bills to the Commons unless ministers cave on Brexit.The report, drawn up with the help of lawyer and ex-MP David Howarth, lays out four options for Parliament to take control of the process.In a foreword Tory Remainer Dominic Grieve said: There are routes not yet properly explored, examined or voted upon which the Prime Minister appears to be attempting to close off.Instead Downing Street threatens a catastrophic No Deal should the Prime Minister’s deal fail to be delivered through Parliament.As parliamentarians, we have a duty to examine every option open to us which would avoid such an outcome.”Mrs Mays deal will go to a vote in Parliament in mid-January - but the PM needs to win over dozens more MPsshe is to avoid a humiliating defeat.If the Government loses, Britain will be on course to leave the EU without a deal, but MPs are likely to put pressure on Mrs May to hold a second referendum instead.She has always insisted thats out of the question, but earlier this month ally Amber Rudd suggested it would be better than a No Deal outcome.

title: brexit deal theresa may commons jeremy hunt
story: In a boost for the under-fire PM, the Foreign Secretary insisted she has a good chance of success in next months Commons vote.Mr Hunt called on Brussels to fix the hated Irish backstop - saying that would be the key to getting the deal done.Dozens of MPs say they fear the backstop, meant to keep the Irish border open, will tie Britain to EU rules forever.Mrs May is scrambling to secure a time limit for the proposal to reassure Brexit rebels the UK will be able to leave it.Mr Hunt told the BBC: The EU has agreed that the backstop is temporary and what we need them to do is define what temporary is.So my view is this is not the time to be talking about what other major changes we might be faced with making because actually we can get this through.We can get this through, absolutely can.He insisted the ball is now in Brussels court, adding: If it is temporary then Parliament can live with that, but you need to show us.So I am a supporter of Theresa Mays deal with those qualications to the backstop.I think MPs, as they reflect on how close we are to an agreement, but also how cataclysmic it would bewe didnt end up having an agreement we could get through Parliament, the best thing is to put our heads down and make sure we have a version of this agreement that we can get through Parliament.The deal is expected to come to a vote in the week starting January .Mrs May had to call off the original vote, scheduled to take place before Christmas, because she was on course for a heavy defeat.But she is increasingly confident of winning this time around as nervous MPs worry about a No Deal outcome or a second referendum.

title: clock change eu british summer time brexit
story: The EU has dictated that all European countries should stay on a single time zone all year round.And the UK is likely to follow suit - even though were leaving the EU in three months.Official emails show Britain is set to adopt British Summer Time permanently, ditching Greenwich Mean Time for good.The change was announced earlier this year by top Eurocrat Jean-Claude Juncker.Its now emerged that aides from the Department for Business contacted civil servants in Northern Ireland to discuss the UKs response.In one email published by the Daily Mail, a senior figure told a colleague: My impression... is that officials advice is likely to be in favour of adopting British Summer Time all year.The official added thatthere were dferent time zones in Northern Ireland and the Republic, It could potentially create a need to put clocks back when crossing the border from south to north.The UK has been lobbying to scrap the EU-wide rule change and keep the current regime, with every European country changing the clocks twice a year.If the new rule does end up going through, Britain wont be legally bound by it because we will have left the EU.But ministers may conclude that its simpler to adopt the same regulations as Europe rather than risk confusion.

title: mps slam eu settlement scheme advert
story: A  second video spread on social media featured cheery music and pictures of smiling people to give details of the EU settlement scheme.It also laid out charges of £ for an adult and £. for children that must be paid for them to stay in the UK.As well as being branded a rip off, some also accused the campaign of carrying a veiled threat to deport the EU citizensthey failed to register.The scheme – which will be fully operational by March  - will check the identity, residence status and criminal record of all EU citizens living in the UK.Senior Labour MP branded the adverts “all part of a nasty, closed-minded, closed-country attitude”.The SNP’s immigration spokesman Stuart McDonald MP said: “These adverts highlight the horrible consequences of Brexit and Theresa May’s obsession with ending free movement of people – both are grave mistakes”.Labour’s shadow home secretary Diane Abbott added: “The Home Office attempts to process the over  million EU nationals entitled to register under settlement scheme is a disaster waiting to happen”.So the Home Office’s sinister demand that they “apply” to stay here after we leave the EU, with the silent threat of imminent deportation, strikes all the wrong notes.Of course there will be paperwork involved. But there is a dference between ensuring control of our borders and straight-forward hostility.Language will be vitally important as we show the world we remain a global nation that is open to those who want to work hard and get on.Between these tone-deaf messages and the inability to patrol the seas off Dover — with potentially tragic consequences — we are seriously concerned that the Home Office isn’t up to it.Sajid Javid has work to do.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit theresa mays team pin
story: NewsBrexit: Theresa Mays team pin hopes on EUs Jean-Claude Juncker to save her dealEXCLUSIVE: Despite his brutal put-downs a top No official claimed the EU chief is "put on this earth to negotiate"ShareCommentsByPippa Crerar:,  DEC NewsDowning Street is pinning its Brexit hopes on Brussels chief Jean-Claude Juncker "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDowning Street is pinning its Brexit hopes on Brussels chief Jean-Claude Juncker being able to successfully encourage EU leaders to agree to more concessions on Theresa May’s deal. One senior aide to the Prime Minister told the Mirror the eurocrat was the UK’s “best hope” of reaching agreement with the EU, conceding that he was “put on this earth to negotiate”. The Government is now hoping to get other EU leaders to sign up to a start date for the UK’s trading relationship with the bloc which could mean the controversial Irish border back stop could be avoided. They believe this could be done without reopening the orce deal, which Brussels has ruled out, but could nevertheless carry the legal force demanded by the PM’s Brexiteer critics.  Donald Tusk, the influential European Council President, will also play a key role in whether sceptical EU states can be persuaded to offer more. Britain’s focus is now on pushing for enough assurances from Brussels to get the Democratic Unionist Party, who the Tories rely on to prop up their fragile Government, on board, in the hope sceptical Tories will follow. However, the senior No  insider admitted that Mr Juncker and Mr Tusk have their work cut out in winning over the likes of French president Emmanuel Macron and Irish premier Leo Varadkhar. They conceded that December’s Brussels summit could have gone better, with Mr Juncker describing the PM’s Brexit plans as “nebulous and imprecise ” and Mrs May leaving virtually empty handed. “A lot of this will come down to Juncker and how much he wants to get a Brexit deal. He was put on this earth to negotiate. We hope that he’ll be able to help us get what we need to get the DUP on board,” the source said.  Other government insiders claimed that talks just before Christmas with the DUP had been more promising than before, when the party firmly ruled out backing Mrs May’s deal. Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt yesterday warned that the EU must provide further assurances over the backstop, the fall-back plan for the border,the PM’s deal is to make it through Parliament. He told the BBC the backstop was the only “outstanding issue” and he believed it could be solved, noting that the EU had already agreed it was temporary. The Brexit deal agreed by Theresa May and the EU covers two areas: the Withdrawal Agreement, covering the UKs exit from the EU, and the Political Declaration on a Future Framework, which sets out the relationship with the EU after Britain leaves. Key details on the Brexit deal include: . The Withdrawal AgreementThe transition period can be extended until  - after the next election Goods face being checked between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK A backstop could extend EU customs rules UK-wide - and wed need Brussels permission to quit European courts will still have a big hold on the UK. The Future FrameworkComprehensive arrangements that will create a free trade area - not exactly the frictionless trade hoped for Possible EU access to British fishing waters We would remain tied to European courts Wed respect human rights laws Visas needed for long term trips to the EU It has built in vagueness - kicking the can down the road for further negotiationsRead about the deal in more depth here. “I think MPs, as they reflect on how close we are to an agreement, but also how cataclysmic it would bewe didn’t end up having an agreement we could get through Parliament, the best thing is to put our heads down and make sure we have a version of this agreement we can get through Parliament,” he said. His remarks came as Jeremy Corbyn urged the PM to cut the Christmas recess short and recall Parliament so MPs can vote on the Brexit deal. Meanwhile, Spanish PM Pedro Sanchez sought to reassure the , British retirees living in his country that their rights would remain unchanged eventhe UK crashes out of the EU without a deal.

title: new year honours list 2019
story: NewsNew Year Honours list  in full - from stars to heroes of tragedy and terrorMichael Palin, Christopher Nolan, Twiggy and Gareth Southgate are among big names in this years list - along with heroes of terror attacks and the Thai cave rescue, plus a political rowShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDan BloomOnline Political EditorThomas Hornall:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror video names-made-new-years-honours-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSupermodel Twiggy, Python Michael Palin and England manager Gareth Southgate are among more than , people awarded in the New Year Honours . The list celebrates heroes - from  responders to terror attacks, to the ers who stunned the world in the Thai cave rescue. But there are also awards for Dark Knight director Christopher Nolan, Downton Abbeys Jim Carter and authors Philip Pullman and Margaret Atwood. And a cronyism row is set to brew after Theresa May rewarded big business chiefs who just happen to back her Brexit deal. There are plenty of famous faces in the honours list - but far more people who quietly work away at doing good for their communities. So to honour them all, we’ve reproduced the list in full - and highlights - below.  Overall, , recipients are named in the  New Year list. That includes the  people recognised for their acts responding to the terror attacks in Manchester and London in . Some  women are recognised in the list, representing % of the total, the lowest percentage since . Overall % of those being honoured come from a black, Asian and minority ethnic background, % consider themselves disabled and % identy as LGBT. Youth magazine founder Saeed Atcha, , is the youngest to be recognised, with an MBE for services to young people and the community in Greater Manchester. The oldest is -year-old World War Two veteran Robert Lingwood, who gets a BEM for services to the community in County Tyrone. The heroes in the community   people who responded to the Manchester and London terror attacks have been named in the New Year Honours. Among them is Special Sergeant Jared Simpson, one of the first officers on the scene at the Manchester Arena on the night of  May last year. Suicide bomber Salman Abedi had just detonated a homemade device laden with shrapnel in the lobby of the Arena at the end of an Ariana Grande concert, killing  people, the youngest just eight years old. “My first thought is always for the victim or victims that have been affected by whatever I am dealing with, and they will always be my first priority,” Sgt Simpson said, after learning of his British Empire Medal for services to policing. Other honours include an OBE for Paul Woodrow, Director of Operations at the London Ambulance Service an OBE for Joy Ongcachuy, a theatre nurse at Barts Hospital and a BEM for Theresa Lam, the Family Liaison Lead for Greater Manchester Police. British ers who helped save a youth football team trapped inside a flooded cave in Thailand are also honoured.   Vernon Unsworth, the ex-pat suing Tesla entrepreneur Elon Musk for labelling him a pedo guy, is among those getting MBEs for their roles in the dramatic Thai cave rescue, which gripped the world during the summer. Divers Joshua Bratchley and Lance Corporal Connor Roe both get MBEs, while four more British cave ers are receiving civilian gallantry awards. Seven firefighters who saved elderly residents from a serious blaze at a care home in Cheshunt in  are also honoured.  Wayne Ansell, Simon Best, Daniel Cooper, Ricky Davis, Christopher Meadows, Radoslaw Przemyslaw Pejka and Simon Waddingham, all of Hertfordshire Fire and Rescue Service, get Queens Gallantry Medals in recognition of their acts. An OBE also goes to Mark Prince for tackling kne and gang crime in London after the heart-rending experience of losing his son aged . No awards will go to anyone involved in Grenfell Tower relief work until the public inquiry has concluded following talks with emergency services and community groups, organisers said. The sports stars  In sport, England football captain Harry Kane gets an MBE while national team manager Gareth Southgate gets an OBE, both for services to football and in recognition of Englands semi-final run at the  World Cup. But fans could be angered by an OBE for outgoing Premier League chief Richard Scudamore - topping up his poundm departure bonus. Former England cricket captain Alastair Cook is knighted for services to cricket while Tour de France champion Geraint Thomas gets an upgrade from MBE to OBE to add to his BBC Sports Personality of the Year  accolade. Former footballer Leroy Rosenior, now vice-president of Show Racism the Red Card, gets an MBE for services to tackling discrimination in sport. Motor neurone disease sufferer and former Scottish rugby player George Doddie Weir gets an OBE for services to rugby, motor neurone disease research, and the community in the Scottish Borders. The political cronyism   Theresa May was embroiled in a cronyism row last night after she announced that a prominent Brexiteer had been made a privy counsellor ahead of her meaningful vote on Brexit. Sir Edward Leigh, who has yet to announce how he will vote on the deal, said earlier this month that the Prime Minister’s efforts to secure concessions from Brussels could yet pay off. Two other Tory MPs who have both said they will back the Prime Minister’s plans were also appointed to the secretive official body - Philip Dunne and Sir Roger Gale. It came after hardline Brexiteer John Redwood - one of the Eurosceptic Cabinet ministers branded “bastards” by John Major - was knighted in the New Year’s Honours list. With the crunch vote due next month, speculation has been swirling at Westminster honours may be deployed as a means of luring MPs to back the Prime Minister. In an apparent bid to reassure supporters that he will not be swayed by his gong, Mr Redwood published a blog just days ahead of the announcement outlining “Eight things wrong with the withdrawal agreement”. Tory MP Gary Streeter, who backed Remain in the  referendum and has already made clear that he will support the PM, also received a knighthood. Tory donor John H J Lewis, who has given thousands of pounds to the party, was awarded an OBE for philanthropt and supporting the arts. Airbus UK chief Katherine Bennett, whose company had warned it might reconsider its investment in the UK in light of Brexit, but has now offered cautious support for the PM’s plan, gets an OBE. German-born Siemens UK chief Juumlrgen Maier, who has also backed Mrs May’s deal over crashing out without a deal, receives a CBE. Labour party chair Ian Lavery said: “It is insulting to those who make valuable contributions to society that the Tories for years have continued to use the honours system to award their own Conservative grandees and party donors.” Whitehall honours include a knighthood for HMRC chief executive Jon Thompson who received death threats after disclosing that a customs option preferred by Brexiteers would cost up to poundbn. Knighthoods also go to Richard Heaton, the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Justice, Laurie Bristow, the UK ambassador to Moscow who dealt with the fall-out from the Salisbury poisoning and Roy Stone, who has served under seven PMs, latterly as an aide to the chief whip. Mrs May’s deputy principal private secretary, William Macfarlane, gets a CBE for public service.STARS OF THE ARTS Twiggy   Twiggy joked that it has been purgatory keeping the news of being made a Dame a secret. The model, born Lesley Hornby and dubbed the worlds first supermodel, has been awarded the title in the Queens New Year Honours list for her services to fashion, the arts and charity. The -year-old told the Press Association: Its wonderful, but it makes me giggle. When we wake up every morning we turn to each other, my husbandand I, and we just giggle. So its a very nice, warm feeling, and obviously I am very honoured. The hardest thing has been keeping it a secret, because weve known for about three-and-a-half weeks. Christopher Nolan  ChristopherNolanis one of the most acclaimed filmmakers of the st century and among the highest grossing directors of all-time. His work on the Dark Knight trilogy as well as movies including The Prestige, Inception and Dunkirk brought him blockbuster success as well as an Oscar nomination. Now, the -year-old can add a CBE to his already illustrious CV after being recognised for services to film in the New Year Honours. In a  interview with ,Nolan, who holds dual UK and US nationality, lamented the lack of support he received in the country of his birth while trying to break through in the film industry, reflecting: But theres a very limited pool of finance in the UK. To be honest, its a very clubby kind of place. In Hollywood theres a great openness, almost a voracious appetite for new people. Michael Palin   The former Monty Python star, who gets a knighthood in the Diplomatic Service and Overseas list for his international contributions to travel, culture and geography, said news of the accolade had not sunk in yet. He said: I dont think it will be until I see the envelopes addressing me as Sir Michael Palin. I have been a knight before, in Python films. I have been several knights including Sir Galahad and the knight who said, ni. He added: I am so very pleased that I was able to sort of morph from being Python and becoming a traveller, or a presenter of travel programmes. That gave me the chance to see an enormous amount of the world. Margaret Atwood  Canadian novelist Margaret Atwood, author of the feminist dystopian work The Handmaids Tale, becomes a member of the Order of the Companions of Honour for services to literature. She is alone this time round in receiving the highest honour it is possible to bestow in the New Year list. Philip Pullman The creator of the hugely successful His Dark Materials trilogy said he was very surprised and honoured to receive a knighthood for services to literature. He added: Im most grateful of all to those who continue to read my books, and I hope they dont have to work as hard as those who edit them. Jim Carter Carter, who played Mr Carson in the hit British period drama Downton Abbey, said he was delighted his OBE for services to drama came in time to be seen by his -year-old mother, who lit up at the good news. He added: Im hoping for a  of good news and kindness. It seems perilous times and it would be good to get a bit of kindness, sanity and good cheer back into the world. BEST OF THE REST Broadcaster and naturalist Chris Packham said our wildle needs a voice to shout above the noise after being awarded a CBE for services to nature conservation. John Clough, whose daughter Jane was murdered by her ex-boyfriend, gets an MBE for his campaigning for victims of domestic abuse. He is joined by Andrea Aviet, who runs a charity helping abused women and young people, and who gets a BEM. Stagecoach co-founder Ann Gloag is to be made a dame for services to business and philanthropy, and former CEO of Virgin Money Jayne-Anne Gadhia also gets a damehood for services to the financial industry and to women in the industry. Bafta-winning actress Thandie Newton, who starred in Oscar-winning film Crash and more recently the futuristic drama Westworld, gets an OBE for services to film and charity. The Gruffalo authorJuliaDonaldsoncalled for an end to the closure of libraries as she was awarded a CBE. Daphne Self, the worlds oldest working professional model at , gets a BEM for services to women and fashion, while the editor-in-chief of Harpers Bazaar Glenda Bailey becomes a dame in the overseas list for services to the GREAT Britain Campaign and UK prosperity, charity, fashion and journalism. Actress Sophie Okonedo, who starred in Hotel Rwanda and more recently in Antony and Cleopatra at the National Theatre, has her OBE upgraded to a CBE for services to drama. Dr Helen Pankhurst, a senior adviser at CARE international, and great-granddaughter of suffragette leader Emmeline Pankhurst, also gets a CBE, for services to gender equality. There is an MBE for Claire Turnham, founder of the Victims of Viagogo group, which helps customers reclaim money on event tickets, for services to consumer rights. Consultant plastic surgeon professor Simon Peter Jabir Kay, of Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust, will get an OBE for services to complex reconstructive hand surgery, including hand transplantation. story: NewsBoxing Day hunt: Horric footage of fox savagely killed by houndsWARNING: DISTRESSING CONTENT A hunt saboteur grabbed the dead animal and carried away to stop the dogs ripping it apartShareCommentsByAnita MerrittKelly-Ann Mills:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video fox-killed-by-hounds-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShocking footage showing a pack of hounds killing a fox on Boxing Day is being investigated by police. The video has emerged as crowds of supporters have turned out for the annual Boxing Day hunts across the UK. The footage was allegedly filmed in Devon and has caused many to call on the government to strengthen legislation banning hunting with hounds.Devon County Hunt Saboteurs say the footage was captured during the Eggesford Hunt at Place Farm, on the edge of Okehampton, according to DevonLive. A spokesman said: When our sab team arrived the fox was barely alive, with its guts hanging out, and died in the arms of a young female saboteur.  A Devon and Cornwall Police spokesman said: Today we have been made aware of an incident near Okehampton on Boxing Day involving allegations of offences against the Hunting Act. The matter is being investigated and police would like to hear from anyone who witnessed the incident. We would encourage witnesses to any offences to share unedited footage and images with us, and to be prepared to give statements to allow us to investigate any allegation of criminality. We are aware of the sensitivities and the high-emotions that are linked to these incidents. All allegations connected with hunts are assessed and investigated appropriately and we work with our communities who have an interest in hunt activity as part of routine policing. We wish to reassure the public that we will act impartially and promptly to any incident reported to us, and would urge anyone with relevant information to contact Devon and Cornwall Police via . Ahead of the hunts, shadow environment secretary Sue Hayman said an incoming Labour government would review penalties under the Hunting Act  to ensure it is an effective deterrent. It would include a consultation on the introduction of custodial sentences, bringing it in line with the penalties for other wildle crimes.  Ms Hayman said they would also consider measures to prevent the exploitation of loopholes in the legislation, which covers England and Wales. It could include the introduction of a new recklessness clause to prevent trail or drag hunts being used as cover for the illegal hunting of wild mammals. Ms Hayman said they would also look at removing an exemption for the use of dogs underground to protect game birds as it risks fights between hounds and wild animals. Labours  Hunting Act was a key milestone in banning this cruel blood sport, but since then new practices have developed to exploit loopholes in the legislation, she said. While Theresa May proposed scrapping the Hunting Act all together, Labour is today calling time on those who defy the law by announcing several measures that would clampdown on illegal hunting. Labour is the true party of animal welfare. These new proposals form part of the next chapter in striving to ensure our laws and regulations on animal welfare are up to date and fit for purpose. Grove and Rufford Hunt chairman Nick Alexander criticised Labours plans, saying there is more to prioritise in the world than beefing up hunting legislation.  He spoke as the hunt ed to Bawtry, near Doncaster in South Yorkshire, a year after it was refused permission to meet in the centre of the town following the convictions of three people for hunting offences. Of Labours plans he said: Its not welcome. It just seems a bit bizarre that theres lots of other things going on in the world at this time and,thats the priority, then someone needs to have a word. Standing among the crowds, he added: Look at all this. This is the real truth of the matter. Hunting is very much part of England - old England and modern England. And were here to stay.

title: brexit divided least sun
story: NewsopinionBrexit ided us - but at least we got some sunThanks to the shambolic handling of Brexit,  was suffocated by a story that split the nation and made Britain a global laughing stock.ShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  DEC NewsopinionRead dubbed Mamma Mia Here We Go Again an abysmal corn-fest"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen online events group VidCon asked its followers to sum up  in four words, the printable replies went on the lines of “I wanna die thanks” and “please end it now”. So I’m not going to sell you a pup. It was bad. Thanks to the shambolic handling of Brexit,  was suffocated by a story that split the nation and made Britain a global laughing stock. But it wasn’t all bad. We had a glorious summer, the royals let a woman of colour into their ranks, North and South Korea agreed to formally end their war, Ireland repealed its abortion ban, England reached a World Cup shysemi-final and Trump didn’t blow up the planet. So here are my awards for ’s great, good and not-so good... Best joke  The Tories sent a campaign letter to an elderly couple, purportedly from Theresa May, addressed to “Mr Youmustbe F***ingjoking”. Banksy made a mockery of arts snobbery by shredding one of his paintings that had just sold for poundmillion. More people voted to put slab-headed footballer Harry Maguire riding a unicorn on a bank note than Margaret Thatcher. Nick Clegg, the man who did more to alienate schoolkids from politics by lying about tuition fees, was made a “sir”. But nothing had us rolling in the aisles more than the two Russian hitmen who poisoned the Skripals, claiming to have been in Salisbury because they were fascinated by the size of its cathedral spire. Best sight There was the auction of Nigel Farage’s National Portrait Gallery painting which failed to attract a single bid. There was Gareth Southgate’s waistcoat in Russia, which proved that mad dogs and Englishmen do go out in the C sun dressed for a wedding. There was the blimp of the US president flown above London during his UK visit which looked like Donald Trump impersonating Elvis Presley when he’d become so obese he couldn’t control his bowels. But on a personal level it has to be the closing credits of the abysmal corn-fest that was Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again. Best Trump outburst  When asked to rate his presidential performance, the humble introvert replied: “I give myself an A-plus”. To howls of laughter he told the UN General Assembly that his administration had “accomplished more than almost any in the history of our country”. To much grimacing he told Kim Jong-un that he had a bigger nuclear button than him. But nothing summed up the ignorant racist philistine more than when he asked, during a discussion on visa limits for people from Haiti and Africa: “Why do we want people from all these sh**hole countries here  We should have more people from places like Norway.” Best quote  Tory peer Jeffrey Archer hopefully spoke for the nation when he said: “I’d vote for CorbynI lived in the North because half of what he says I find myself agreeing with %.” Tory MP Johnny Mercer definitely spoke for it when he called Theresa May’s Government a “sh**show”. But taking gold, despite being three years old, was David Cameron’s masterclass in irony before the  election, which was on most of our minds every day of the year: “Britain faces a simple and inescapable choice – stability and strong Government with me, or chaos with Ed Miliband.” How did that pan out  Best man  Those Thai cave rescuers showed magnicent ingenuity when they helped a trapped boys’ football team to safety. Raheem Sterling showed admirable courage, not just for taking on the racists at football grounds, but by kicking off a debate about how the media treats young black men. However, there could only be one winner: Danny Dyer, for calling out, live on TV, the architect of all of our misery, David Cameron: “How comes he can scuttle off  He called all this on. Where is he  Hes in Nice, with his trotters up. Tw*t.” Still makes me proud, that. Best woman  There was a big breakthrough in TV writers making us realise women could pen some of the funniest shows out there: Lisa McGee’s Derry Girls, Julia Davis’s SallyEver, and Phoebe Waller-Bridge’s Killing Eve. Radio presenter Rachael Bland showed us all how to die with humour, dignity and courage when cancer claimed her, aged . But for giving the world a smile in a tough year I can’t look past porn star Stormy Daniels who claimed having sex with Donald Trump was the “least impressive” she’d had, mainly because his penis “has a huge mushroom head like a toadstool”. Worst man  James Dyson told us Brexit would liberate UK industry then announced his new electric car would be built in Singapore. David Davis resigned as Brexit Secretary after barely speaking to counterparts in Europe for two years then signed up for an after-dinner speaking agency. Tony Blair was never off the airwaves telling us about the disaster of Brexit to make us forget all about his disaster in Iraq. But the winner had to be the odious Boris Johnson, who whipped up hate with his burka letterbox jibe and resigned from a disastrous spell as foreign secretary to plot and lie his way to Number . Worst woman  Nadine Dorries told us it was “time for a charismatic figure like Tommy Robinson to be running the country”. Roseanne Barr finished her career when she tweeted that black businesswoman Valerie Jarrett was the product of a sex act between “Muslim brotherhood  planet of the apes”. And Jo Marney, the girlfriend of ex-UKIP leader Henry Bolton, spewed out Katie Hopkins-style tweets. But the winner is the most disloyal Labour MP in living memory. The one who has made a career being elected by working-class Labour voters of Vauxhall to represent shire voters who like hunting, DUP supporters and the Jacob Rees-Mogg tendency of the Tory Party: Kate Hoey.

title: couples christmas ruined after broken
story: NewsCouples Christmas "ruined" after broken lt leaves them trapped on th floor of tower blockLyn and Stephen Phillips say they have been “trapped” since Christmas Eve and were forced to eat a cheese sandwich for their Christmas dinnerShareCommentsByKate WilsonKelly-Ann Mills:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video lt-broken-bristol-flats-over-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA married couple has said they and the residents of  flats are prisoners in their own home after being left without access to a lt for Christmas. The two lts in Winterstoke House, Ashton Gate, Bristol - which shares an estate with two other high rises - have been out of order since Christmas Eve. There are  flats within the building, which houses people over  years old, many of whom have health complaint, according to Lyn and Stephen Phillips, who live on the th floor. One of the lts was reported broken to Bristol City Council earlier this month and residents have been told that engineers were waiting on a part, Bristol Live reports. But then around pm on Christmas Eve the second lt in the building broke down - leaving the dozens of residents who live there without any lt at all. Have you had a Christmas nightmare  Email webnews@mirror  Bristol City Council has said engineers were sent out the same day to fix the lt but they have been unable to keep the lt operational. The council has also apologised to residents who have been inconvenienced as a result of the broken lts and said getting at least one lt working was a “top priority”. But this has done little to appease those residents who face up to  flights of stairsthey want to leave their own home. Lyn and Steve say they have been “trapped” since Christmas Eve. Lyn, who is -years-old and suffers from angina, said her Christmas has been “ruined” as result. She said that the pair ended up eating a cheese sandwich for their Christmas dinner as they were unable to leave the building and travel to their daughter’s house where they were supposed to spend the day. “I have already had a heart attack and am currently trying to fight off a chest infection with antibiotics, so there is no way I could climb  flights of stairs,” added Lyn, whose husband Steve is an insulin dependant diabetic. “Christmas was completely ruined for us.  “We have become prisoners in our own home. It’s absolutely disgusting.” The pair, who have lived in Winterstoke House for four years, said engineers had been visiting the building on and off since Monday trying to fix the lt. “Occasionally they would get it working again but then it would break again a couple of hours later,” she added. “I don’t want to leave the building and then not be able to get back into my home - or even worse get stuck in the lt when it breaks down.” But the pair said it was not just themselves they were worried about, but the other residents who live in the building who they say are a lot worse off than them. “We have people in their nineties living here, people with mobility issues who rely on the lts to get in and out of the building,” added Lyn. Debra Sainsbury said she is worried about her -year-old mother Maureen who lives on the fth floor of the building.  “Some of the people living in these flats are vulnerable older people so this whole experience has been really horrible for them,” she added. “My mum has had to tackle five flights of stairs in order to get out of the building.” Ms Sainsbury has also said she is worried about emergency services being able to access the building. Winterstoke House has a buzzer system which allows residents to buzz in any visitors from their own flat. Once buzzed into the building visitors have access to the lts, but in order to access the stairs they need a key fob to open another door. This means that residents have to walk down the stairs to the bottom floor in order to let any visitors into the building - this includes emergency services. Bristol City Council has said that the fire service has special key fobs that allow them access to council buildings, therefore they would not have an issue entering Winterstoke House. But other emergency services would need to have the door opened by the caretaker or a resident to get access to the stairs while the lts are broken. “It’s just really worrying to think about what would happenmum, or any of the other residents, had an accident in their flat and couldn’t get down the stairs to let the ambulance service in,” added Ms Sainsbury. Signs have been put up in the building informing residents of the issues with the lts by the lt company Stannah.  A typed note on one of the lts says: “Dear tenant, due to the non availability of a replacement lt motor drive unit for lt number one, we have had to remove the existing unit to vendors for repair. “Unfortunately due to the holiday period we cannot be guaranteed a deliverydate. “We will refit the repaired unit as soon as it is available. “Stannah apologise for any inconvenience this may cause anyone.” But now a handwritten note has been added to the bottom of the signs which says: “Apologies both lts are now out of order awaiting parts. Please contact the council for updates. “Sincerest apologies for the inconvenience.” In a statement on Wednesday, Bristol City Council said the contractors had been back on site, and it was hoped that one lt would be up and running by the end of yesterday. A spokesperson added: “We apologise to residents of Winterstoke House for any inconvenience caused by the broken lts – especially at this time of year when friends and family may be visiting. “The fault on the second lt was reported to us at around pm on Christmas Eve. “An engineer attended the same day, and was able to get the lt operational, but unfortunately it then broke down again. “The other lt has been out of action for ten days, and we are currently waiting for a part to be refurbished. We hope this will be done in early January. “However, making sure at least one lt is working has been a top priority for us. Caretaking staff are also on site to help vulnerable residents throughout the day.”

title: mum left swollen burnt face
story: NewsMum left with swollen and burnt face after allergic reaction to box hair dyeCharlotte Cragg, , from Kendal, Cumbria, said she was left looking like a monster after having an allergic reaction to at home hair dyeShareCommentsByElaine McCahillNews Reporter:,  DEC NewsCharlotte Cragg was left with a swollen and burnt face after suffering an allergic reaction to home hair dye "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum was left with a swollen and burnt face after suffering an allergic reaction to box hair dye. Charlotte Cragg, , from Kendal, Cumbria, is warning others to do a patch test before using at-home hair dye after she was left looking like a monster. While her face has reduced back to its normal size, the scary experience has inspired Charlotte to speak out in the hopes of helping others to avoid the same fate. She said: “I learnt the hard way to always do a patch test evenyou’ve used a product before. “I’ve not been put off dying my hair but I’ll definitely be more cautious in future. Although I probably should have known better since I’m a trained hairdresser.”  Charlotte, who is a midwery students, says shes been dyeing her hair for  years and has never had an allergic reaction until now. She said: “I’ve always been really girly and loved changing my look. “I’ve been every colour under the sun from purple, red, brown, blonde and black. “Thankfully I never suffered an allergic reaction. I’ve always had my hair dyed in a salon and been given a patch test every time.” However, this isnt the first time shes had a bad reaction to a beauty treatment.  When she was  in , she suffered a bad infection after getting a black henna tattoo on her arm. The tattoo turned into boils after she had a bad reaction to the paraphenylenediaminein the tattoo. Since then Charlotte has been careful to dye her hair using colours that dont have PPD. Despite being a trained hairdresser, she didnt carry out a patch test when dyeing her own hair for the first time in May .  Charlotte said: “I bought two boxes of hair dye in cool brown and coloured my hair. “I did a patch test beforehand and followed the instructions as normal. “That night, my head was a bit itchy but I never thought anything of it.” But her reaction was much more severe in July when Charlotte decided to dye her roots before heading out to celebrate her th birthday. Her scalp soon became itchy and the next morning she woke up looking like Sloth from the Goonies. When I woke up the next morning my ears had puffed up and my head was boiling hot, she said.  “That day, I went to a local pharmacy where the pharmacist recommended antihistamines and a topical cream to put on my face. “I hoped the tablets would help my symptoms settle down quickly. “Instead they worsened, my face swelled up and my head felt like it was on fire. “My throat was sore and I had jaw pain. I looked like Sloth from the Goonies. “My kids, Max, six, and Ollie, four, were terried of me and said I looked like a monster. “Ollie cried when he saw me and refused to go near me. If I tried to kiss him, he ran off.”  Charlotte sad she looked like shed had a stroke as her face was droopy and her eyes were completely swollen shut. She was diagnosed with prolonged anaphylaxis, which an allergic reaction that develops slowly. Within three days her face was back to normal and says she now only uses hair dyes that are paraben-free.

Kira has started a dance class, is doing really well at school and has become a typical teenager. There are still many things that she wont be able to do but she has done so well. Kira has started to love fashion and has asked for make-up for the first time this year. She keeps up with the latest trends, she is a completely new person. Im so proud of her. Kira, from Ulceby, Lincs., has had more than a dozen major surgeries in her le already - including the -hour operation at Liverpool’s Alder Hey Children’s Hospital to lt her sunken face.  The surgery involved inserting metal plates into Kira’s face before fitting her head with a metal frame - which she then had to keep on for three months. Since having the frame removed, the brave teen has struggled at state school from bullies - but has been moved to another specialist school where she is now thriving. Michelle, a full-time carer for Kira, said the cruel taunts never stopped her daughter. She said: The children can be so cruel. Kira knows she is dferent but doesnt understand why at this point. As she gets older she is asking more and more questions [about her condition]. Since she moved schools, Kira has done so much better. She is happy now and has a lot of friends.  Apert syndrome is a condition involving abnormal growth of the skull and the face due to early fusion of certain sutures of the skull. Children with the condition have bulging eyes that are usually wide-set and tilted down at the sides. They are known to have problems with teeth alignment due to the underdevelopment of the upper jaw while some have cleft palate. Among other anomalies, children with Apert syndrome have webbed fingers and toes.  It affects one in every , babies. While she had the frame on her face, Kira incredibly continued to be able to feed herself. She now attends a dance class and loves watching Youtube videos and spending time with her new friends. Michelle, who also shares two older children, Ryan, , and Victoria,  with husband Mark Yates, , added: She loves everything to do with fashion now. She has bought herself some trendy new leggings and is keeping up with all of the trends of her friends. Kira is just like any other schoolgirl. The surgery has allowed her to be more independent. There is light at the end of the tunnel now. To find out more information about the condition visit: https:www.facebook groups apertsyndromeawareness

title: duck extinct 15 years back
story: NewsDuck extinct for  years back from brink to become worlds rarest birdThe Madagascar pochard duck rapidly declined in population to the point of near extinction due to human impact in their African homelandShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  DEC NewsThe Madagascar pochard duck rapidly declined in population to the point of near extinction "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA duck thought to be extinct for  years has been brought back from the brink - and is now believed to be the worlds rarest bird. The Madagascar pochard duck rapidly declined in population to the point of near extinction due to human impact in their African homeland. But now,  of the ducks have spent a week in the safety of the worlds first floating aviaries on Lake Sofia in the north of the country.Gloucestershire-based Wildfowl and Wetlands Trustsaid this pioneering approach is to enable the birds to become accustomed to their new surroundings, increasing the chances they will remain at the site after release.  The state of the wetlands in Madagascar is so poor they will likely not survivethey leave the lake. The ducks were released from the aviaries in December and very quickly adapted to the lake, ing and flying, associating with other wild ducks and ing to the safety of the floating aviaries to feed and roost. Experts from WWT, Durrell Wildle Conservation Trust, The Peregrine Fund and the Government of Madagascar have spent years laying the foundations for the birds introduction.  With a wild population of just , the duck may be the rarest bird on the planet. Nigel Jarrett, head of conservation breeding at the WWT, said: It takes a village to raise a child, so the old African proverb goes, but in this case it has taken a village to raise a duck. We have been preparing for this moment for over a decade. The logistics of working in a remote part of Madagascar - where access to the lakes by vehicle is only possible for three months a year - have been an enormous challenge, requiring us to come up with novel approaches. Working with local communities to solve the issues which were driving this bird to extinction has been essential to giving the pochard a chance of survival.

story: NewsRussian state broadcaster RT slammed for sending chocolate Salisbury Cathedral as gtRT sent chocolate models of the Salisbury Cathedral as a festive gt months after ex-spy Segei Skripal and his daughter were poisoned in the city in MarchShareCommentsByElaine McCahillNews Reporter:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsRussian state broadcaster RT sent a chocolate model of Salisbury Cathedral as a festive gt "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Russian TV station has been slammed for sending chocolate models of Salisbury Cathedral as festive gts. State-run broadcaster RT sent the chocolate gts to members of the media and others claiming it reflected one of the biggest news stories of the year. Politicians in the city, where ex-spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia were poisoned with Novichok in March, are said to be furious about the disrespectful gt. Salisbury MP John Glen said: This is bizarre behaviour but to be expected. title: after defeat by celtic dundee boss says this weeks games are the ones that really count
story: Moments after Dundee’s - defeat at Celtic Park, manager Jim McIntyre’s thoughts turned straight to what he calls “two huge games” this week.The Dark Blues were condemned to spend Christmas as the Premiership’s bottom side after champions Celtic swept them aside with embarrassing ease.The Dens gaffer was disappointed with the manner of his side’s defeat but acknowledged this week’s games against Livingston and St Johnstone are where Dundee have a better opportunity to pick up some much-needed points.He said: “My whole thought process is we have two huge games coming up at home.“We need to make sure we are picking up points in these two games. They’ll be huge for us.”To add to the Dark Blues’ woes, St Mirren picked up a victory at Motherwell to leave them three points adrt at the foot of the ision.Adding points to his own team’s total is more important to Jim, however – as is bringing in new faces next month.“What St Mirren do isn’t our concern,” Jim added.“It’s all about what we do and we have to make sure we continue to just think about ourselves.“The transfer window is going to be important for all of the clubs at the bottom, it’s an opportunity to try to get players in to help the ones we already have.”The Dark Blues did hold out against a dominant Celtic for almost the entire first half with his team’s organisation pleasing the manager, though the manner of the opening goal didn’t.He said: “It was a deserved scoreline.“Celtic were very good, their movement was so fluid, they caused us loads of problems.“I thought our organisation defensively was very good for  minutes but concentration levels are so important.“The timing of the goal and our player stopping for offside was the key disappointment.“It was onside, our video boy confirmed at half-time it was onside, so that was disappointing, just play to the whistle and argue about it later.“A couple of minutes before half-time you’re looking to get in at - and regroup, try to address where Celtic were hurting us.“In the second half Celtic were just too good for us, simple as that.”
